basics-booleans_key2: Booleans are  special type of constants, (till now we have studied about`Strings`, `Integers` and`Floats` ).
basics-booleans_key3: Boolean values are of two types:
basics-booleans_key6: These Boolean values help us in doing some interesting things. We can use them to do some really interesting work.
basics-booleans_key7: If any  `variable` is `True` then we tell the computer to do something and if it is `False` then we tell the computer to do something else.
basics-booleans_key8: As of know this much understanding is enough but we will study it in depth further :)
basics-booleans_key10: Whenever we ask any question to computer then we use some special type of `operators` to ask these questions. These `operators` always give answers in Boolean form i.e. either '`True` or `False` '.All the `operators` are listed in the `tab`le given below.
basics-booleans_key16:
7 < 6 # `False` Why because 7 is greater than 6
6 < 10 # `True` Because 6 is less than 10
basics-booleans_key18: Which is less than equal to?
basics-booleans_key19:
7 <= 10 #`True` because 7 is less than 10
23 <= 23 # `True` because 23 is equal to 23
basics-booleans_key22:
varx = 10
varx == 10 # `True` because varx is equal to 10
67 == 43 # `False` because 67 is not equal to 43
basics-booleans_key24: Which is greater than equal to?
basics-booleans_key25:
56 >= 32 # `True` Because 56 is greater than 32
43 >= 70 # `False` because 43 is neither greater nor equal to 70 .
basics-booleans_key28:
number1 = 43
number1 > 20 # `True` because number1 contains value 43 which is greater than 20 .
basics-booleans_key31:
45 != 45 # `False` because 45 is equal to 45
45 != 34 # `True` because 45 is not equal to 34.
basics-booleans_key32: Play with all these `operators` in `Python` `shell`. You will gain a better understanding.
basics-booleans_key33: If you will use these `operators` in `Python` `shell` then it will automatically show its Boolean answer.
